Comment: We've already seen about a degree of warming, three more is not far fetched. 

3 degrees can be a big problem. Imagine you're a farmer in western Saskatchewan. The only reason the western prairies are NOT a desert, is because the long deep winters provide moisture as snowpack, and keep evaporation down.  3 degrees will lengthen the evaporation season, shorten the moisture-sustaining winters, and lead to a significant expansion in the "Palliser's Triangle" region where it's too dry to grow crops without irrigation.  

Oh, did we mention the rivers that that irrigation relies on are glacier-fed; large parts of Ab/SK and a bit of Manitoba are "non-contributing" and are net-sinks of runoff to the degree that large tracts of SK don't actually drain anywhere, and there is a real risk those glaciers will melt meaning that basins like the Sask. River and its upper tributaries will no longer flow in summer... meaning you can't irrigate to make up for it?

Comment: As usual, Mr. Butt has got a hold of the wrong end of the problem.  Consider:  a complainant alleges a sexual assault; the police investigate and gather evidence; if the police think the evidence is not sufficient they close the file; otherwise they refer the file to Crown Counsel for review; if the Crown thinks that the evidence supports a reasonable or substantial likelihood of conviction, the matter proceeds to trial; at trial the Crown presents its evidence, which is subject to challenge by the defence, and the defence presents exculpatory evidence if it so chooses; the judge or jury weighs the evidence and renders a verdict.

How is the judiciary at fault here?  The fault, if there is one, lies in the nature of the alleged offence not producing credible evidence or in the police not gathering the correct or sufficient evidence (if it exists).

Comment: "Yet, cars and cell phones and groceries haven't skyrocketed in price nearly as much as health care has."
There are a few key differences. Your health and survival don't depend on a car or a phone. Yes, the price of cars and phones have increased, but have you ever seen the price for those go down? I certainly haven't.
Every company is entitled to make a profit. Cigna is a great example. Under a totally free market they would have recently increased their rates 40% but thanks to state regulators they agreed to a mere 30%. Cigna reported near-record profits for last year, which is certainly their right, but what choice do you or I really have? Are there other for-profit insurance companies with "more affordable" rates? I haven't seen one.
Thru zero fault of my own, I'm epileptic. Aside from one seizure about 10 years ago, I'm healthy and active and able to earn a good living. Before Obamacare, not a single private insurer would touch me. How's that for private industry?

Comment: Except in extreme cases of violence or mental illness, the government should do more to keep children and parents together.  Though an unemployed or drug addicted person is not going to make a "good" parent, with some help and supervision, such an individual may be a much better option than a long line of strangers who will never love the child as their own.

Government should try, as a pilot program, a group home / supervised building scenario, where children and parents who need help can live together in their own apartments but have social workers on site to check on the family units.  This may turn out more effective than the existing expensive system of taking children away from parents who most likely love them but need help parenting because they are struggling with some issues.  We may end up helping both the parents and the children if we keep them together.

Comment: You understand that not all 10 carriers are currently at sea, right?

Just because there are 10 carriers we normally only have 2 or 3 actually forward deployed a time. The other carriers are in shipyards doing maintenance that allows them to be forward deployed. I understand that some believe that this is money just being thrown away but at the rate our carriers are deployed we really are at the minimum of carriers we need.

Comment: Marka Brooks - An interesting thing to know about those costly ruts is that they are rarely seen above the Alaska Range. Fairbanks has traffic, people use studded tires, and yet we don't have ruts. Why?

Well, the obvious reason is that our roads are frozen 5-6 months out of the year -- literally asphalt ice. Which is why we need studs ... although you can make due with aggressive tread mud-and-snow (MS) tires. I don't recommend Bilzzaks because they degrade on summer roads, so you either need a new set every winter or a summer and winter set. Blizzaks are also MUCH more expensive than studded tires (although they won't be under Giessel's plan).

So, I'm okay with Anchorage/Juneau being told they can't use studs, but I oppose the entire state being charged extra because studs cause ruts south of the Alaska Range. It's not a problem here in Fairbanks and probably nowhere else north of the Range. A one-size-fits-all "solution" is no solution at all.

Comment: Our experience of Jesus is one of the masculine gender who revealed God as "Father."  Yes, God, in fact, possesses no gender, per se, but it is through the medium of gender identification that He did choose to reveal Himself.
I suggest that it is, rather, the re-imagining of God in our own image (versus that which He revealed) that imposes limits beyond those that our limited capacity for understanding already impose.  The terms of "Lord, Master, Almighty Father, King, the Holy One", as you point out, are not exclusive of others... but they are not incorrect, either.  Jesus may be simultaneously king an shepherd, The First Person may be at once Father and, analogously, a bird (Ps 91:4).  
"What message is being conveyed by our predominant use of titles portraying power and dominance for God?"
I answer that God, Who created us for no other reason than love, is due our worship, regardless of how He chose to reveal Himself, disagreeing theologians notwithstanding.

Comment: In his memoirs of the Falklands affair a senior officer made comparisons between the Marine Commandos who went home to the UK by ship and the Parachute Regiment who were flown home -- both composed of similar persons.
In his view there were many fewer post-action problems in the Commandos than in the Paras because they had time to talk over the issues and experiences among themselves (it is well known soldiers talk only to other soldiers) before dispersal.
Waiting until the PTSD is well established and manifesting itself is far too late, it must be prevented, and prevention comes from recognition of the inciting factors and the symptoms. If a mandatory buddy system were imposed and supervised this might serve the purpose. In a good military organisation the sergeants know their men and act as their surrogate parents, but are all our military organisations so ordered, and are the men recruited suitable to the stress of the task? Who gets to carry a weapon? The lowest IQ's?

Comment: I am not an economist but I did get my Bachelors in Economics. I'm a Keynesian  and I support the financial strategy of the Federal Liberals. But deficit spending is the easy part of Keynesian economics. The ultimate success of KE depends primarily on two outcomes: 1) increased economic growth, check; and balancing the budget over the entire business cycle, tbd. When the economy is doing well, the gov't needs to run surpluses in order to keep the gov't debt from ballooning. (There is lots of room for quibbling on timing, debt to GDP ratios, etc.)  Also important is that, when the gov't is running a deficit, what they are using that money for is. The spending needs to be balanced between structural deficit spending and infrastructure investment. My concern with the gov't's current budget strategy is that I do not know how much of the current deficit is due to infrastructure investment spending.

Comment: Most of the points Ms Wente makes regarding illegal distribution and consumption prevail today under the illegal system. Bringing these practices in from the shadows, however, strikes me as entirely sensible. For example, her assertion that "In Oregon, illegal marijuana still accounts for more than 35% of the market" could also be spun as an almost 65% reduction in the illegal market. Such practices will not be eradicated completely but, with the benefit of transparency provided by legalisation, can be reduced, monitored and controlled to a greater extent than they currently are. It is possible to be ambivalent and question some of the thinking behind the government's legalisation initiative yet still support the policy. There is much to criticise here but it seems to me that is true about most of this government's tenuous grasp when it comes to implementing complex policy. Be that as it may, when it comes to legalisation, we should not let the perfect be the enemy of the good.

Comment: As the author well knows, sexual assault in Canada is not just rape.  It is defined as "sexual contact with another person without that other person's consent."  In the broadest sense it could include as little as an unwelcome kiss in a bar or as much as outright rape.  I think we would all expect the criminal conviction rate on minor unwanted sexual assaults - which are far more common than rape - to be next to zero.  So throwing out alarmist garbage statistics like only 3 out of 1000 sexual assaults result in conviction when the real discussion is about rape is irresponsible and exposes the author to be nothing more than a politically-minded activist and opportunist.  

The goal here should be to find justice - for the victim, for the accused, and for society.  Measuring conviction rates against some sort of contrived scale completely misses the point.

Comment: FYI, Stebbins does not have piped water within town for the general population. There is only a centralized water access from which people haul their water for household use. Years ago, people would cut large ice blocks from local lakes or ponds in winter, and haul them back to town on sleds. I don't think there is enough snow presently, and the ice probably wouldn't be thick enough yet for cutting blocks and pulling sleds anyway. Hauling water by Honda, a few buckets at a time, over better than a dozen miles of dirt road (roundtrip) could obviously be done, but....

Ironically, we are paying $10 billion for rail which will take longer in total travel time than any previous transit system implemented.  When my Tesla 3 arrives later this year, I am driving in with the auto-drive feature and parking free in downtown.   My Leaf does not have the range for a comfortable daily commute.  BTW, today's morning commute via Mililani Express took 41 minutes.  There is nothing wrong with our efficient express bus system yet we are replacing it with an archaic mode of transit that will double the commute times of current public transit users.  Most of us plan to drive rather than use rail.

Comment: The cost to government is not insignificant, but the bigger problem with a high minimum wage is the elasticity of demand for labor. There is absolutely no calculation involving demand for labor that goes into calculating the statutory price floor. Democrats hold a drum circle and decide how much they think people should make and then set out to make it so. Unfortunately, the real world isn't quite as simple as the mind of your average Oregon Democrat. Employers will adapt to the higher cost by moving, investing in automation, or any number of other ways. Comment: @Tweedledee:  You would think that would be the way to go, but unfortunately the Jones Act (aka the Merchant Marine Act of 1920) specifically states that any foreign ship cannot sail to a non-contiguous part of the U.S. which is Alaska, Guam, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico.  That's unfortunately why prices here are so expensive.  Everything has to get shipped to the U.S. Mainland first and then it can be shipped to Hawaii, but only using U.S. Flagged vessels which requires the unloading of goods from the foreign ships and reloaded onto a U.S. Flagged ship (e.g. Matson) and then subsequently shipped here.  The Jones Act exists to protect U.S. shipping companies from foreign competition and to ensure that adequate supply ships exist in times of war.  If U.S. shipping companies had to compete with foreign ones, there would be no U.S. shipping companies because the foreign ones are significantly cheaper since they don't have to pay their crews much.

Comment: "While on the G&M - popular ideas that don't fit the globalist, open borders narrative of this newspaper get silenced by never getting published in the first place or comments that favour that idea get deleted."

This whine comes in different flavors; the "G&M is a neoconservative rag" flavor, the "G&M is a neoliberal rag" flavor, the "G&M is a capitalist rag" flavor, the "G&M is a socialist rag" flavor, and now the "G&M is a globalist rag" flavor.

But, inevitably, that's all they turn out to be--ranty little whines from people who always come back for more.

The Toronto Star and the Toronto Sun very wisely turned off their comments systems. The G&M hasn't done so yet. Why? I don't think the G&M has greater dedication to free speech, I think the G&M likes the revenue from the banner ads.

I don't mean to mock anyone, but--realistically--there's nothing that can be done except to go away and never comment again and deprive the G&M of banner ad revenue.

The chances of that? Zilch.

Comment: If we accept the 90+% failure rate in the 2016 real-world test of TSA sceeners to be representative of the proficiency of the TSA as a whole, then we should also accept that the real role of the TSA is to reassure the traveling public.  Put another, more cynical way, it's just a visible method our government is using to show it's doing something (but not that it actually does anything that justifies the salaries paid or the millions of dollars paid to U.S. companies for the associated hardware, training and maintenance - not to discount the millions of man hours lost waiting in line by the traveling public).

I realize that trying to prove a negative is difficult if not impossible, but just how many 9/11 terrorist attacks do you guess the TSA has prevented since its inception?  Or, if we consider something we CAN measure, just how many would-be terrorists have been caught or prevented from boarding planes by alert TSA screeners?  One?  Two?  Any?

Comment: Your conclusion is not supported by science. The most likely cause of CTE is playing football before the age of 12 and symptoms first appear in 8 to 10 years, so if Hernandez played football at an early age, his symptoms could have appeared while he was at Florida. 

A study cited in the Wikipedia entry on CTE said, "Symptoms of CTE, which occur in four stages, generally appear 8 to 10 years after an athlete experiences repetitive mild traumatic brain injury." 

A recent Boston University School of Medicine study of CTE "showed that participation in youth football before age 12 increased the risk of problems with behavioral regulation, apathy and executive functioning by two-fold and increased the risk of clinically elevated depression scores by three-fold. The increased risk was independent of the total number of years the participants played football, the number of concussions they reported, or whether they played through high school, college or professionally."

Comment: For those claiming Trudeau broke his promises, you were obviously not paying attention to him.  In an interview on January 22, 2014 with Metro reporter  Robson Fletcher.

"Pipeline policy in general is one of the most important responsibilities of a Canadian prime minister and of a Canadian government – to make sure we can get our resources to market. We are a natural resource economy and we need to be able to do that. ... Comment: The proposal to erase Sir John's name from public schools may be a bit of an overreach, but perhaps not and, in any event, certainly not by much. As one of the architects of residential schools, he made this argument:

“When the school is on the reserve, the child lives with its parents, who are savages, and though he may learn to read and write, his habits and training mode of thought are Indian. He is simply a savage who can read and write. It has been strongly impressed upon myself, as head of the Department, that Indian children should be withdrawn as much as possible from the parental influence, and the only way to do that would be to put them in central training industrial schools where they will acquire the habits and modes of thought of white men." 

I think that's what we call prima facie evidence for advocating cultural genocide. I also think it's reasonable to question whether or not his name belongs on institutions where children are taught.

Comment: No doubt you're right about many modern refectoria. But back in my monastery-visiting days, late 80s, early 90s, I ate in four Benedictine houses (Mount Saviour, Portsmouth, Christ in the Desert, and the one just east of Cuernavaca where Mount Angel monks were rebuilding), and recall that everyone was served at table, save for one evening at CitD, when we milled about in the kitchen serving ourselves.

So far as I can tell, "tricliniaria" is not a common word in classical lit, with only one ref in the OCD (Varro, about a shaded dining room for use in summer). Anyway it seems an odd and unnecessary development from the much more common "triclinium." I don't know anything about how it may be used by Christian authors. For that matter I don't know how long the implication that such a room is where one reclines to eat persisted: at a certain point, could one sit in a chair in a triclinium?

The solution is proven, a universal national health care system for all that is managed through a single public procurement process based on accountability and quality in health care delivery. Comment: I agree. I always caution my coworkers to not present 72 or 84 month terms to their customers. Its not good for the customer and bad for the salesperson. In the event the customer does want to trade in their car at 48 months they are in a negative equity position.

The reality is cars are a depreciating asset. It's best to lease and consider the buyout at the end. Leasing means your not paying all the PST GST up front and if you do have a bad accident or writeoff you can return or walk away from the car much better without taking a hit. If it's been a good car and still meets your needs just buy it out at the end of the lease.

Comment: When I first came to Alaska, Regional schools were the trend.  Students came from small communities, some of which were over 500 miles away.  Many of the students lived in dormitories and some lived with host parents.  It was heart wrenching to know a 13 or 14 year old that was away from family for the entire school year; 9 months.  Academically the schools were able to offer course with teachers with subject mastery. These larger schools were able to offer classes in course such as carpentry that simply could not be taught in a tiny school with 12 students ranging in age 8 to 17.  


I've known many adults who were graduates of boarding school system in Sitka back in the early days. They seem to have done well as members of society, many went on to college, many own businesses.  But there are those who could not handle being away from home who simply dropped out without  graduating. 

Any ideas of returning to this system needs more than a cursory review.

Comment: I was born in Kakaako in 1937.  Moved to Kalihi when I was about 8.  My memory is a community of diverse cultures, household heads being grandparents. Pidgin the 3rd. Language of the children who played together.  No sidewalks, just good, old dirt to play marbles. Mixed in, a candy factory on the corner of the block.  Naval supply depot (use to be a race track), barbed wire fencing about 2feet from the house we used to hang the wash.  Ice truck came by once a week, and the Manapua man selling his  buns and dim sum.  An rooms-to-let apartment complex owned by a Russian man. Kodak's big building where I use to slide down its smooth, concrete ramps.  This was a neighborhood, a village, a wonderful place to call home.

Comment: You might want to read some of the legal analysis written about the R. v. NS ruling. It's simply not a broadly applicable precedent, other than that the court established a test concerning the applicability of a Charter exception in relation to conflicts intersecting with the rights of those facing criminal charges. The more applicable Canadian legal precedent is R. v. Keegstra, where it was determined that a fundamental Charter right (in that case freedom of expression - perhaps the most important right in a democracy) could be infringed for the purposes of balancing competing rights and interests and enforcing broader social objectives, which I believe is almost perfectly analogous to the ECHR's decision on the Belgian veil ban. We've already pried open the Pandora's Box of Section 1 exceptionalism where Charter infringements are concerned.

Comment: JR:

The 2006 International Residence Code (IRC) which is currently in use in Honolulu requires smoke alarms in Section R313 in new homes and in additions which add bedrooms.

The 2006 International Building Code (IBC) which is currently in use in Honolulu for larger buildings and townhouses requires smoke alarms in Section 907.2.8.

Existing buildings have always been exempt from mandatory upgrades to the current code.  Otherwise construction work would be continuous.  However, if you want a permit to do something to your existing house, (depending upon the planned work) you may be legally forced to upgrade.

Comment: Not all police officers see their jobs as full time careers.  They join and leave just like a bank teller, postal clerks, reporters and checkout clerks. I have seen them leave to become attorney's and go on to become judges.  I have seen them leave because the work did not suit them or because they subsequently got hired by the fire department.  Some leave to become stay at home mom's or because the are unhappy.  On the obverse, I have seen some stay their full careers that should have never been hired.  Shift work, hazardous duty, strict internal discipline does not appeal to all workers. There is a high probability that a sworn officer may leave the department. before he/she reaches retirement age.  That is a given.  And all things considered that is a good thing.  Why be unhappy at work?

Comment: "the states have been able to skirt the marijuana."

Obama chose to ignore the Federal law on marijuana and the Congress didn't make even medical marijuana legal.

Medical marijuana was already declared subject to Federal prosecution.   

Gonzales v. Raich, 545 U.S. 1, 14 (2005); see 21 U.S.C. §§ 812(c), 823(f), 841(a)(1), 844(a).  Thus, except as part of “a strictly controlled research project,” federal law “designates marijuana as contraband for any purpose.” 

But  the 9th Circuit has ruled that medical marijuana cases can't be prosecuted as long as Congress keeps renewing the refusal to fund those particular prosecutions.  U.S. v McIntosh (2016)

http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2016/08/16/15-10117.pdf

AG Sessions is free to prosecute all the non-medical marijuana cases he wants at whatever level he wants even in Colorado, Washington, Oregon and Washington D.C.

If Congress doesn't renew the "no funding clause", he can go after the medical marijuana people, too.

Comment: My husband I were foster parents. We had 73 + kids over the years. With a few exceptions, all of those kids went on to be successful in life. 
Most of the kids we had were teenagers, girls, who had blown out of other placements. Some stayed with us a few days but other kids stayed past their 18th birthday so they could graduate from high school.
It wasn't anything really that we did, it was that most of these kids were extremely resilient!  Survivors!
Many had survived horrendous childhoods filled with sexual abuse and/or physical abuse.
Some had good beginnings in their own families but due to circumstances ended up in the system.
20 years have pasted since our last foster daughter graduated and moved on with her life. She is a grandparent herself now and has done wonderfully over the years despite having come from one of the saddest backgrounds.
We hear from and see the "girls",many who are approaching 50's and are grandparents now. They had the tenacity to survive and thrive !

Comment: Yves reports on the public facts, the surface, the  optics. Let me fill in the unseen:

1. U.S. knows it cannot bully or defeat China. Too big, too powerful, too much know-how. It's strategy is to separate China from Russia. It won't succeed, but any degree of separation is a win for the U.S. We shall see. 
2. U.S. wants China help, at least non-interference as it tries to knock out North Korea. It will get nothing. Because as long as there is a massive U.S. military in South Korea, Japan, Guam, China need a North Korea as buffer, as tool for its protection.

Comment: "Safety first, unless you're too busy." That's what a co-worker said when the carpenters pulled the walls away and dropped a ceiling on my head as they rushed to dismantle a stage set while I was inside it removing fixtures. Luckily, it was a canvas flat and did no harm.

Safety is an issue when things are booming. You get more new people who don't yet know what's unsafe.

12 hours-plus is a standard work day in the film industry. The hours Mr Apa worked that day were the hours that the entire crew of 50 or more people works, 5 and sometimes 6 days a week, for the duration of the production, weeks or months. Things may have changed since I left it, but in 13 years in the film industry in Vancouver the only time the production ever mentioned paying for a hotel room was when no one could get home that night because the highway was shut down.  It would put a major wrench in the budget if even half the people in the crew said "I'm tired, I can't drive home" every second night.

Comment: "Alaska’s prison population has grown by 27 percent in the last decade, almost three times faster than the resident population. This rapid growth spurred the opening of the state’s newest correctional facility–Goose Creek Correctional Center–in 2012, costing the state $240 million in construction funds. On July 1, 2014, Alaska’s correctional facilities housed 5,267 inmates, and the Department of Corrections (“DOC”) had a fiscal year operating budget of $327 million. Absent reform, these trends are projected to continue: Alaska will need to house an additional 1,416 inmates by 2024, surpassing the state’s current prison bed capacity by 2017. This growth is estimated to cost the state at least $169 million in new corrections spending over the next 10 years. The rising cost of Alaska’s prison population coupled with the state’s high recidivism rate...have led policymakers to consider whether the state is achieving the best public safety return on its corrections spending." Comment: The current winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes is not in the U.S. Constitution. It was not debated at the Constitutional Convention. It is not mentioned in the Federalist Papers. It was not the Founders’ choice. It was used by only three states in 1789, and all three of them repealed it by 1800. It is not entitled to any special deference based on history or the historical meaning of the words in the U.S. Constitution. The actions taken by the Founding Fathers make it clear that they never gave their imprimatur to the winner-take-all method. The winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes became dominant only in the 1830s, when most of the Founders had been dead for decades, after the states adopted it, one-by-one, in order to maximize the power of the party in power in each state. 

The constitutional wording does not encourage, discourage, require, or prohibit the use of any particular method for awarding a state's electoral votes.

Comment: AkCal:  Stories like this can be very important, and life-saving!  Not just because it speaks of the great heroism of Mr. Jenkins but because it teaches us about some of the problems in the sport of kayaking that we all can learn from.  I have been a pro-rated skydiver since 1985 and we have a magazine for our sport that publishes each and every mishap (Incident reports) with the same kind of information as that contained in this outstanding story.  It has long been recognized as the most important section of that publication and most skydivers will tell you it is the first section they read.  That is because everyone acknowledges that the information contained in those reports may very well be responsible for saving their own life.  Instead of asking why this story was ever put in the paper, you should be encouraging that even more like it gets published.  Any news that can make us better and safer in the Alaskan outdoor sports we all love so much is definitely GOOD NEWS to read!

Comment: John,
A few points of clarity-
1. The cost of the track itself is $1 Million.  The school has been offered a gift of that full amount. 
2.The additional costs included in the bond are for field improvements to both the existing Dahl Field and the new fields that would be installed in the center of the track (suitable for football, soccer or 2 junior soccer fields).  These improvements were included because it makes sense and saves money to do the work while the track and the new music room construction is underway.
3. The proposed track surface is rubberized and sits on porous concrete.  It will provide a solid non slick surface even in our rainiest weather.
4.  There is a $1.2 Million endowment given by the same donor family already established.  This will distribute $50-60,000 annually and will cover all required maintenance and then some.
Not all gifts are worth accepting, but this one sure makes economic sense to me.  
All the best, Hilary

Comment: Unless I am missing something, I see no explicit mention of any constitutional basis for the US presence [or claim of sovereignty over] the Hawaiian Islands in this thoughtful piece, though the issue of lack of authority is implied. The US is a State organized on the idea of 'limited powers' and US Constitution does not grant to the US government the authority, or power, to unilaterally annex another internationally recognized State. Nor is unilateral annexation a 'power' inherent in a State under international law. The possibility of a 'treaty-based' annexation exists, and has been used, the Virgin Islands is an example, but not a 'resolution-based' annexation, the Texas matter was 'ratified' via a treaty with the Mexican State. So the legal propositions, unless I am missing something, goes something like this. No treaty, no annexation, no US sovereignty. No constitutional power to obtain international title via resolution, no US sovereignty. Cheers.

Comment: Utter nonsense. Nagasaki and Hiroshima were targeted specifically because they were heavily populated civilian areas. The whole idea was to shock the Japanese imperial command into surrendering by demonstrating the horror of the bomb. It was a cold, calculated and deliberate attack on a civilian population.

The A-bomb wasn't produced to destroy factories, and nobody in their right mind believes that was the intent at Nagasaki and Hiroshima. And even if it were, the fully predictable and inevitable collateral damage would still have made dropping the bombs morally unjustifiable by any reasonable standard, and certainly by the standard of Catholic moral teaching.

I don't judge Truman or the U.S. military. I'm sure they did what they thought was right. But what they did is still objectively horrific, and nobody who rationalizes it has any ground to stand on in criticizing the brutality of others.

Comment: Let's not call it greed, Professor Haycox, let's call it individualism because that's what it really is in non-partisan terms. It is not everyone's cup of tea, but at the time it was conceived a couple of centuries ago or so, it was very new, and it served as an immense magnet to immigrants from Europe. 

Although there are plenty of examples of greed in our society, it is a fact that Americans want the same things that hominids have wanted for the past million of years or so: a safe place to have a family, resources to feed that family, and freedom to do what we want to do. We Americans are genetically predisposed by our immigrant roots to fight for these things a little more forcefully that others would. The people who weren't willing to change their scenery stayed where they were. America is composed, mostly, of the children of the world's restless.

We don't need academics to shame us. We need academics to help us learn to channel our individualism in mutually beneficial ways.

Comment: Kevin, once again we see a contradiction in terms from you:  With respect to Rome's futile ban on contraception, you say, "... refusing to fully partake in His creation by deliberately denying another the opportunity of life, is sinful and this is known innate by mankind," simply does not comport with reality and is therefore false. In order for something to be accepted as a "basic innate truth" it has to be demonstrably "true" which it is not.

Comment: First off the article you quoted was for April numbers, not the current report which shows Ontario's unemployment rate at 6.4%.  The April numbers appear to be a statistical anomaly as they went from 6.4% in March to 5.8% in April then 6.5% in May and now 6.4% in June.

Second, both the general decline in unemployment in Ontario and particularly the statistical anomaly in April were driven largely by a decline in the participation rate, ie fewer people looking for jobs.

Ontario's unemployment rate has barely budged in the past year, going up from 6.3% to 6.4%.  Our employment rate has declined and our participation rate has declined by 0.1% and 0.2% respectively..  For the country as a whole the employment rate and participation rate are both up, by 0.5% and 0.4%.

Put very simply, the figures aren't all that positive for Ontario for the past year.

Comment: Just don;t get it do you. Try this:

Morguard and Hunt dealt with the enforcement of judgments between Canadian provinces, which under Canadian law have the jurisdiction to regulate enforcement of foreign judgments with respect to most areas of law. However, the Supreme Court specifically noted in Morguard the need in the modern world economy “to facilitate the flow of wealth, skills and people across state lines in a fair and orderly manner.” As such, these cases must be considered in assessing the issue of the enforcement of foreign judgments in Canada.

Canada’s lower courts have almost universally applied the Morguard principles of enforceability to judgments originating outside Canada’s borders. This extension of Morguard has considerably simplified the enforcement procedure for foreign litigants.

Comment: The question isn't so much if someone is an addict before or after they abuse drugs, but rather how do you correct the behavior?

What motivates a drug addict? The desire to be deviant and break the law?  Or have they become mentally ill and are unable to help themselves? The answers to these questions should determine wether incarceration or treatment will be more effective in preventing the behavior when they are released, which is what we all hope happens with the tax dollars we spend for crime prevention. 

There's interesting research that points to treating addiction versus jail time in being more effective at putting people on the right path. It's easy to think "bad people go to jail" but you have to ask what the point of jail is. Is it just to remove the undesirables from society or is it truly a "correctional facility" that's supposed to reform people? Probably a bit of both, but I think we all want to see people who are released to not be a danger to themselves or others.

Comment: As near as I can tell a problem with pre-build UP forecasts is they never realistically factored in all various costs to potential users. Things like time cost to schlep to and from stations, along with possible monetary costs. Potential for appearance costs on wet, snowy and hot days.  Potential navigational issues for visitors; so much easier to jump in a taxi or limo and relax. 
Taxi time costs are competitive or even better for much of the day from most locations.  25 minutes for about 25km is not 'express' in my train books. 
Taxi dollar costs were competitive with two pax, and better with three than the original $27 fare. 
Original promotional BS of comparing UP Express to London's Heathrow Express were blind to all the foregoing and scale differences. On the subject of scale, I wonder if those little UP trains could be lengthened if the project were ever a success? Or are there station restrictions.  If so, are they capable of frequency increases?

Comment: Obviously you need to consider all of the available options before you even begin to negotiate price.  If there are discounts that can only be used on a cash purchase you need to factor that into the equation.

But regardless of how you ultimately plan to pay for the car you need to focus on obtaining the best price first and how to pay for it second.  The sales people only want to deal in payment terms because 1.) it obscures the actual total cost; 2.) payments quoted in weekly amounts sound much more manageable that they really are.

So negotiate the best price possible including all discounts that you are aware of.  Then push for the zero % or best rate possible.

Comment: No kidding, China has more people than Canada? I never knew that. However, the number of people does not change the point.

People often resist the idea of having multiple languages for knee-jerk reasons. It's too costly, they're a minority and should speak our language, blah blah blah. Yet the reality is that China prospers even though it has hundreds of spoken languages. 

It's even more interesting when you consider that China has an authoritarian government. If they wanted they could just tell everyone to speak Mandarin or else. But they don't. The government of China officially recognizes 56 different ethnic groups in the country. They don't see multiculturalism and multilingualism as a threat. Yet you'll still find Canadians who- 50 years later- condemn the fact that we have even two official languages.

Comment: Left Turns at intersections with heavy traffic causes delays. 
--
Traffic congestion in Waianae most likely comes from the existence of Left Turns at several intersections because traffic must come to a halt for Left Turn.
****
Except that the 21st century has come up with a new and innovative intersection design that lets vehicles make a left turn simultaneously with traffic moving forward.
--
In other words, traffic will not and would never ever come to a halt anymore for Left Turns. 
****
So, without Left Turn at all intersections and with traffic lights synchronized - traffic at Waianae could flow smoothly, with timing that enables vehicles to go thru several intersections without stopping.  
****
The new and innovative intersection design is called Continuous Flow Intersection or CFI such as those in Maryland, Missouri, New York and Utah.
****
Problem is how existing intersections can be remodeled into CFI without affecting traffic at the intersection.

Comment: I'm personally skeptical of the idea that rape is a complicated subject and that rapists rape people because they're not sure that it's wrong or because they didn't get enough "education" about "rape culture."  I don't think that's generally how it works.  I think it's rather obvious when sex is consensual and when it's not.  In general, the only real complications tend to occur whenever we expand the definition of "rape" to include things like drunken sex (not to be confused with unconscious rape) or "non-affirmative consensual sex."  Regret sex is not rape.  This is not PC, but it is true.  Smart kids can tell the difference.

I don't think Brock Turner raped the girl because he didn't realize it was rape.  He did it because he didn't think he would get caught, just as thieves steal things believing they won't get caught.

And questioning a person's judgment, by the way, isn't "victim blaming."  If my friend gets robbed in a bad neighborhood, YES, I DO ask what he was doing there.

Comment: I hope I'm wrong about Trump, too, for the sake of the country and of the world; I'm trying to leave a corner of my mind and of my heart open to the possibility that he will prove me wrong.  But we're off to an inauspicious start: the nomination of Sessions suggests that the Trump administration will embark on a full-bore assault on the civil rights (especially the voting rights) of minority communities; and the appointment of Steve Bannon -- a white supremacist and anti-Semite -- is a signal to the hard right, to the alt-right, that Trump will continue to espouse and promote the causes that are dear to them.  The merger of the presidency with the Trump corporate empire and with the Trump family is especially troubling.
As for Republican opposition to Trump: over the course of the 2016 campaign, Republican opposition fluctuated between tepid and impotent, with a huge share of cowardice. In the end, they all caved.  We won't see a new edition of "Profiles in Courage" any time soon.

Comment: Neat site...which you are misinterpreting. It only shows the perspective from certain mountain tops, Pike's Peak for example.  And looks very much like what it looks like when you are on one of these.  Of course you can see farther standing on a high point like that.

I'm not sure I understand your question you are asking me to agree to.  I would agree that at sea level the horizon is about 2.9 miles, but if you go up just 100 feet, the horizon distance goes to over 12 miles.

Lastly, your concept that objects "never are" below the horizon is faulty.  I've seen many examples, but probably my favorite is being in a place called Niagara-on-the-lake. Its is on the other side of Lake Ontario from Toronto.  From there you can only see the very tops of many buildings, but not the shorter ones.  Or, having lived in Los Angeles, you can only see the peaks of Catalina Island from the beach, but on the hills you can see the whole thing. Your "simple concept" simply doesn't reflect my experience.

Comment: Goldman is kind of ignoring the cycles of the oil industry.  Majors are making more now because they stopped investing in growth.  But, the longer you go not investing in growth, the higher chances you end up with an oil shortage.  If the oil shortage is too large, you spike oil product prices and kill demand for them.  At the same time, the price spike spurred new investment, and just as that demand is dying, you can get a wave of new expensive production coming online, and the whole industry crashes again.

What is happening now is unsustainable.  Majors may get some quarters of bragging they made money at $50 oil by not investing in anything, but it can never last.

Comment: I was cool with what I had when employed by an entity that provided health insurance to their employees via a group plan.  When I stepped away from that occupation (family decision), I went to work in a company that didn't offer insurance until you were there for 6 months.  I then discovered how things worked.

I made the mistake of choosing to be born pre-disposed to high blood pressure.  I found a great $5000 deductible plan.  Fast forward 6 months.  Company is beginning massive layoffs.  I am among the last wave of people laid off.  I soon thereafter began working part-time in an area below my qualifications (so as not to be on unemployment), which was supplemented by substitute teaching during the upcoming school year.  I managed to work anywhere between 40-70 hours a week....with no company insurance.

Low and behold, I chose to develop a herniated disc in my neck, which I began treatment on via physical therapy (as opposed to surgery....so I could continue to work).

To be contd.

What about all of us who had good plans before Obama care that we paid a portion of ourselves, without a subsidy ?  
Might comment was and still is that under Obamacare my family's premium increased even though it was NOT part of the exchange. It has caused us hardship and not helped us. 
So for the millions of Americans who had good insurance before Obamacare came along, more people then those who signed up for Obamacare, now either have had our premiums increased or had it canceled and in some cases had previous benifits dropped because of something in the Obamacare law. 
If I wanted "free" health care I can get it from Indian Health Services via my Tribal Health. 
I rather have a choice in my medical care as far as providers, hospitals, and the treatment/care I receive.

Comment: We can not control God's plans and his power for the ways that we will all leave this Earth. In this world, we all need to keep our minds ready for anything. Don't wonder off doing anything you want. Teach younger ones the ways of our Land and Culture. Teach younger ones subsistence hunting and the dangers of our Alaskan Weather. Don't let facebook and technology take over Alaskan Native life. Teach our younger ones what Alaska is, a place where we need to live to survive and learn to survive when you are trying to survive already.
